lasa_medications.potential_risk: Administering an antidiabetic agent instead of a diuretic, leading to ineffective treatment of glaucoma or edema.
Substitution with an anxiolytic, potentially causing unaddressed depression symptoms.
Confusing with a sulfonylurea antidiabetic drug, risking hypoglycemia or unmanaged psychosis.
Mixing up with an antidepressant, leading to unintended ovulation induction or untreated depression.
Administering an immunosuppressant instead, which could result in untreated infection or transplant rejection.
Confusion between two agents with different dosing regimens, potentially leading to overdose or therapeutic failure.
Misadministration between two inotropes with different indications and dosing, affecting cardiovascular support.
Substituting with an antihistamine, leading to unmanaged hypertension or unnecessary sedation.
Confusion between two opioids with different potencies, increasing the risk of overdose and respiratory depression.
Mixing up two barbiturates with different uses and potencies, potentially causing overdose or therapeutic failure.
Confusing with an antidepressant, leading to unmanaged pain or depression.
Confusion between two agents with different indications and dosing, potentially leading to therapeutic failure or toxicity.
Mixing up with an anticonvulsant, leading to unmanaged anxiety or seizures.
Administering the wrong cephalosporin, potentially leading to ineffective infection treatment.
Confusing with an antidepressant, leading to unmanaged pain or depression.
Confusion between two antidiabetic medications, potentially causing hypoglycemia or inadequate blood sugar control.
Mixing up with an anticonvulsant, leading to untreated HIV infection or unmanaged seizures.
Confusion between two calcium channel blockers with different dosing, affecting blood pressure control.
Substitution between two SSRIs, potentially leading to therapeutic duplication or withdrawal symptoms.
Confusing with an antimalarial, leading to ineffective treatment of arrhythmias or malaria.
Mixing up with an anti-inflammatory agent, leading to untreated infection or inflammation.
Confusion between two sulfonylureas, potentially causing hypoglycemia or inadequate blood sugar control.
Confusing with an antihistamine, leading to unmanaged psychosis or unnecessary allergy treatment.
